articles.headline: Coffers Empty, California Pays With I.O.U.’s
articles.snippet: Vendors and taxpayers awaiting refunds will get i.o.u.’s as the governor and state lawmakers continue to wrangle over how to close a $27 billion budget gap.
articles.abstract: Vendors and taxpayers awaiting refunds will get i.o.u.’s as the governor and state lawmakers continue to wrangle over how to close a $27 billion budget gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  An ever-widening budget gap joined with intractable political paralysis to deliver California its biggest fiscal blow in decades on Thursday, when the state’s controller began printing i.o.u.’s in lieu of cash to pay taxpayers, vendors and local governments.

articles.headline: U.S. Faces Resentment in Afghan Region
articles.snippet: A new American military operation in southern Afghanistan may ignite further tensions among a weary population, officials warn.
articles.abstract: A new American military operation in southern Afghanistan may ignite further tensions among a weary population, officials warn.
articles.lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  The mood of the Afghan people has tipped into a popular revolt in some parts of southern Afghanistan, presenting incoming American forces with an even harder job than expected in reversing military losses to the Taliban and winning over the population.

articles.headline: Green Power Takes Root in the Chinese Desert
articles.snippet: Beijing is steering a push toward wind and solar power, while the U.S. is just starting.
articles.abstract: Beijing is steering a push toward wind and solar power, while the U.S. is just starting.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNHUANG, China  As the United States takes its first steps toward mandating that power companies generate more electricity from renewable sources, China already has a similar requirement and is investing billions to remake itself into a green energy superpower.

articles.headline: A Day to Tackle the Financial To-Do List
articles.snippet: Taking time, 10 or 12 hours, to tackle ever-postponed money tasks and clear the books can be lucrative.
articles.abstract: Taking time, 10 or 12 hours, to tackle ever-postponed money tasks and clear the books can be lucrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in high school, my friends and I used to talk fairly often about the need for a “mental health day.” It’s stressful trying to make good grades and get into college, so staying home and spacing out once in a while made a certain amount of sense.

articles.headline: Combative Union Leader Steps From the Shadows
articles.snippet: Richard Trumka, who is running to become the next president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is expected to bring a more combative style to Big Labor.
articles.abstract: Richard Trumka, who is running to become the next president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is expected to bring a more combative style to Big Labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Richard Trumka, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., can boast of something unusual for a labor leader  one of his videos has more than 535,000 hits on YouTube.

articles.headline: S.E.C. May Reinstate Rules for Short-Selling Stocks
articles.snippet: They have been reviled as the bad hats of Wall Street, nefarious traders who cashed in on the market collapse and, some insist, helped precipitate it.
articles.abstract: They have been reviled as the bad hats of Wall Street, nefarious traders who cashed in on the market collapse and, some insist, helped precipitate it.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have been reviled as the bad hats of Wall Street, nefarious traders who cashed in on the market collapse and, some insist, helped precipitate it.

articles.headline: Pay-for-Chat Plan Falls Flat at Washington Post
articles.snippet: A plan to bring editors and lobbyists to the publisher’s home brought a critical reaction from the newsroom.
articles.abstract: A plan to bring editors and lobbyists to the publisher’s home brought a critical reaction from the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations, The Washington Post has been a scrupulous watchdog over the capital’s cozy world of power networking. For a short time, it almost became the network’s host.

articles.headline: U.S. Shifts Strategy on Illicit Work by Immigrants
articles.snippet: The White House is replacing workplace raids and roundups of workers by immigration authorities with a less confrontational approach to employers such as American Apparel.
articles.abstract: The White House is replacing workplace raids and roundups of workers by immigration authorities with a less confrontational approach to employers such as American Apparel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Immigration authorities had bad news this week for American Apparel, the T-shirt maker based in downtown Los Angeles: About 1,800 of its employees appeared to be illegal immigrants not authorized to work in the United States.

articles.headline: Russia’s Neighbors Resist Wooing and Bullying
articles.snippet: Using carrots and sticks, Russia has tried to win over its ex-Soviet neighbors, but they often have other ideas.
articles.abstract: Using carrots and sticks, Russia has tried to win over its ex-Soviet neighbors, but they often have other ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  This was supposed to be Russia’s round in the battle over its backyard. All year, despite its own economic spasms, Moscow has earmarked great chunks of cash for its impoverished post-Soviet neighbors, seeking to lock in their loyalty over the long term and curtail Western influence in the region.
